p: St. Marks National Wildlife Refuge is a wetland‐rich region in one of the five richest biodiversity hotspots in North America (Blaustein, 2008; Noss et al., 2015). The Gulf Coast of the southeastern USA is also extremely vulnerable to sea level rise (Enwright, Griffith, & Osland, 2016). The Refuge consists of 32,042 ha of upland and wetland habitats broadly classified as sandhills, flatwoods, and hammocks. A diverse amphibian community consisting of 31 species (20 anurans, 11 salamanders) can be found on the Refuge (Dodd, Barichivich, Johnson, & Staiger, 2007). Ambystoma cingulatum is confined to hydric flatwoods located in the eastern‐most region of the Refuge, the St. Marks Unit (Figure 1).
